Hence the light dance, the comic page,</br>The social laugh, the idle song,</br>Your charms can only fools engage,</br>And me you have engag'd too long;</br>Away ye pains, disguis'd like joys,</br>Deluding, empty idle toys.

Thou musing, sable-mantled dame,</br>O point me out some lonely glade,</br>Where the loud roar of mirth ne'er came,</br>Nor Comus e'er his revels made,</br>Some lone recess, and all thy own,</br>Divinest Contemplation.

I see, I see the sacred place,</br>The mountain crown'd with nodding pines,</br>On whose green tops, with quiv'ring rays,</br>The pale-fac'd moon serenely shines:</br>I hear the water tumbling down,</br>O'er the old rock, and wave-worn stone.

Ha!  with what awe that antique pile</br>Bears full upon my aching sight:</br>The cloud capt spire for many a mile</br>Directs the lonely wand'rer right;</br>Who, nighted, journeys sad along,</br>Or strives to chear him with a song.

The swelling column clad with moss,</br>The specious window's Gothic sweep,</br>The roof, which half in air I lose,</br>And, straining, half in view can keep,</br>With mingled passions fill my breast,</br>By terror and delight possest.

But Melancholy wafts me on,</br>Slowly I pass o'er many a grave,</br>Whose dust's once name, the chissel'd stone,</br>(Poor monument!) a while doth save:</br>But soon the letters will decay,</br>The stone itself soon wear away.

The bat flits by on leathern wings,</br>His dismal vespers screams the owl,</br>The shard-born beetle drowsy sings,</br>And village-dogs at distance howl:</br>The bell beats one — rous'd by the sound</br>Unnumber'd ravens croak around.

What's this?  a creeping horror thrills</br>Through ev'ry vein, o'er ev'ry limb:</br>My mind a fear unwonted fills,</br>And phantoms seem across to skim:</br>In vain my resolution all,</br>In vain philosophy I call.

What hideous frantic form art thou,</br>With sunken eye and tear-mark'd cheek?</br>'Tis Grief — I feel her influence now,</br>These heaving sighs her presence speak:</br>She paints to view a female shade;</br>Valesia! — dear, ill-fated maid!

And could not then thy form divine</br>A longer date of life obtain?</br>Why wast thou form'd so bright to shine,</br>And, yet alas!  to shine in vain!</br>O my lost love! — She fades away,</br>Though gushing tears implore her stay.

Ye heavens!  cruel and unjust,</br>How could ye strike so good a heart,</br>Crumble perfection into dust,</br>And such a soul and body part?</br>How could ye bid us virtue love,</br>And her chief seat so soon remove?

But, hush!  I hear a voice begin,</br>Softer than summer's ev'ning-breeze:</br>Cease, thou fond youth, cease thus to sin,</br>Nor dare arraign high heav'n's decrees;</br>For know they all are good and wise,</br>Though hid from mortals darken'd eyes.

In the fair nymph you mourn, you saw</br>The pow'r omnipotent display'd,</br>Display'd to teach your minds that awe,</br>You owe the being all things made;</br>Then loos'd from earth she upward flew,</br>To endless pleasures ever new.

Then impious say not Heav'n's unjust,</br>And all in vain Velusia born;</br>Nor need'st thou grieve that she is lost,</br>For ever lost to thee forlorn!</br>She is not lost, but gone before—</br>Then be resign'd, — and adore.</br>
